title: About MODES
content: MissionMODES aims to promote research and education in model-driven design and the mining of software repositories. The laboratory focuses on modeling, transformation and analysis of software systems, and on techniques to mine repositories to automate and optimize software engineering tasks such as code and model generation.A central element of the platform will be recommender systems that support decision-making in critical software engineering tasks. These systems will analyze heterogeneous data — for example, code repositories, historical change logs, or developer interactions — and provide tailored suggestions to improve workflows and outcomes. Typical use cases include suggesting appropriate design patterns, recommending reusable components, or automatically flagging potential defects based on historical bug patterns.Objectives  Promote research in model-driven software design.  Develop and integrate repository mining techniques to extract actionable insights from project history.  Provide teaching tools and resources for undergraduate, graduate and doctoral courses on MDE and software mining.  Support automatic completion systems for software engineering tasks (code generation, model generation, test automation).  Publish research results, share tools and datasets, and participate in international conferences and collaborations.ConclusionsThe virtual MODES laboratory offers the DISIM department at the University of L’Aquila an opportunity to become a reference point for research and development in MDE and software mining. The lab will provide a rich environment for experimentation and education and will promote open sharing of tools, data and models.

title: MODES Lab
content: Model-driven research            Advancing software engineering with models and mining techniques.                                                                          Industrial collaborations            We work with industry partners to transfer research into practice.                                                                          Open tools &amp; data            Open-source tools, datasets, and reproducible experiments.                                        Previous            Next                                        MODES — Model-Driven Engineering and Software Mining LaboratoryThe MODES laboratory (Model-Driven Engineering and Software Mining Laboratory) is proposed at the University of L’Aquila within one of the most active international research groups in Model-Driven Engineering (MDE). The MDE group at L’Aquila has participated in several European projects (e.g., OSSMETER, TYPHON, CROSSMINER, LOWCOMOTE, LearnPad, MOSAICO) and in industrial research collaborations (for example with Rete Ferroviaria Italiana).MODES expands the group’s research toward recommender systems for software engineering, with a special focus on modeling. In particular, the lab will explore and develop advanced “model assistants” — intelligent tools that help create and manipulate models — by combining MDE techniques with software-mining and modern machine learning methods.Visit the pages above to learn about our people, research lines, projects and how to get in touch.

title: People
content: MODES Lab — Key PersonnelDr. Juri Di RoccoRole: Lead - ResearcherEmail: juri.dirocco@example.comResearcher focusing on Model-Driven Engineering and software mining. Lead of the MODES laboratory.Prof. Davide Di RuscioRole: Full ProfessorEmail: davide.diruscio@example.comDavide Di Ruscio is a Full Professor at the Department of Information Engineering Computer Science and Mathematics of the University of L’Aquila. His main research interests are related to several aspects of Software Engineering, Open Source Software, and Model-Driven Engineering (MDE), including domain-specific modelling languages, model transformation, model differencing, coupled evolution, and recommendation systems. He has published more than 200 papers in various journals, conferences and workshops on such topics. He has been in the PC and involved in the organization of several workshops and conferences, and he is a reviewer of many journals like IEEE Transactions on Software Engineering, Science of Computer Programming, Software and Systems Modeling, and Journal of Systems and Software. He is a member of the steering committee of the International Conference on Model Transformation (ICMT), of the Software Language Engineering (SLE) conference, of the Seminar Series on Advanced Techniques &amp; Tools for Software Evolution (SATTOSE), of the Workshop on Modelling in Software Engineering at ICSE (MiSE) and of the International Workshop on Robotics Software Engineering (RoSE). Davide is on the editorial board of the International Journal on Software and Systems Modeling (SoSyM), of IEEE Software, of the Journal of Object Technology, and of the IET Software journal. Since 2006, he has been working on different European and Italian research projects by contributing to the application of MDE concepts and tools in several application domains (e.g., service-based software systems, autonomous systems, open-source software systems, and hybrid polystore systems).Prof. Alfonso PierantonioRole: Full ProfessorEmail: alfonso.pierantonio@example.comAlfonso Pierantonio is Full Professor in the Dipartimento di Ingegneria e Scienze dell’Informazione e Matematica of Università degli Studi dell’Aquila. From Jan 2016, he is visiting full professor at the Mälardalens University (Sweden). Alfonso’s expertise lies in the area of software engineering and, in particular, model-driven and language engineering and low-code with special attention to co-evolution techniques, consistency management, and bidirectionality. Recently, he has been focusing on the classification and clustering of modeling artifact repositories. He has been on the organizingv committees of several international conferences and is a member of the steering committee of the MoDELS conference. Alfonso is Editor-in-Chief of the Journal of Object Technology, in the Editorial Board of the Journal of Software and System Modeling, and on the Science of Computer Programming advisory board. He is (co-)principal investigator of several research and industrial projectsProf. Antonio BucchiaroneRole: Associate ProfessorEmail: phuong.nguyen@example.comGamification GOD.Prof. Phuong Than NguyenRole: Associate ProfessorEmail: phuong.nguyen@example.comResearcher working on model assistants and recommender systems for software engineering.Dr. Claudio Di SipioRole: Post-doc / Research FellowEmail: claudio.disipio@example.comPost-doc working on software mining and empirical studies.Dr. Riccardo RubeiRole: Post-doc / Research FellowEmail: riccardo.rubei@example.comResearcher with interests in software analysis and automated code generation.Dr. Damiano Di VincenzoRole: Post-doc / Research FellowEmail: damiano.divincenzo@example.comWorks on model transformations and tool support for MDE.Dr. Giordano TinellaRole: Post-doc / Research FellowEmail: giordano.tinella@example.comResearcher in software mining and data-driven engineering tools.MODES Lab — Key Personnel  Lead: Dr. Juri Di Rocco  Faculty: Prof. Davide Di Ruscio, Prof. Alfonso Pierantonio  Researchers: Dr. Juri Di Rocco, Dr. Phuong Than Nguyen  Post-docs, research fellows and students: Dr. Claudio Di Sipio, Dr. Riccardo Rubei, Dr. Damiano Di Vincenzo, Dr. Giordano TinellaIf you would like to be added to the people page with a short bio and photo, please send the details (name, role, short bio, and a square photo) to the contact address on the Contact page.

title: Research
content: Research LinesThe MODES laboratory focuses on the intersection of Model-Driven Engineering (MDE) and software repository mining. Main research directions include:  Model-driven software design: modeling languages, model transformations, model analysis and tool support.  Software repository mining: extracting knowledge from code histories, issue trackers and developer interactions.  Recommender systems for software engineering: tools that suggest design patterns, reusable components, and implementation hints.  Automated completion and generation: code and model synthesis, test automation, and model assistants powered by data-driven and AI techniques.Infrastructure and ToolsThe lab is primarily virtual and relies on a software infrastructure that includes:  UML and modeling editors (e.g., MagicDraw, Modelio)  Access to trained models and LLMs for research on model assistants and code/model generation  Commercial modeling systems (e.g., MetaEdit+) for advanced modeling scenariosThese resources will enable experiments combining MDE and modern machine learning approaches to produce reproducible and reusable research artifacts.
